huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This unit is a General Season hunt unit and is not managed to be a trophy unit but every year a few really nice bucks are taken.  Hunters should be aware of the Ute Tribal Lands and learn the boundaries.  Public hunting is not permitted on Tribal Lands.  There are many CWMUs on this unit and a list of these can be found on the UDWR webpage.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
ATTENTION-The US Forest is planning on a few prescribe burns this fall that might interfere with some hunters hunt. Please be aware. Salt Lake City, Utah, September 13, 2019 – Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest fire personnel plan to conduct a prescribed burn in the Sheep Creek area September 18, 2019 – November 30, 2019 when weather conditions allow.  The project area is located in Utah County, approximately 30 miles east southeast of Spanish Fork, Utah, and northwest of Soldier Summit from Highway 6.  The burn unit includes approximately 5,927 acres. This prescribed burn is part of a vegetation project that included mechanical treatment in 2013 through 2017.HWY 150
Upper Provo, approximately five miles east of Kamas on the north side of Hwy 150 (Mirror Lake HWY). between Upper Setting and Norway Flat roads. The burn area reaches to the top of the ridge above Shingle Creek. The burn window is sometime between September 1st and December 1st.
West Fork of the Duchesne drainage. Burn area is ten miles west of Hwy 35 near Hanna, Ut. Burning will be targeted on the south side of the river from the reservoir to Little West Fork. The burn extends from the river bottom to the ridge. The burn window is sometime between September 1st and December 1st. Here is a link to the USFS facebook page for more information.
https://www.facebook.com/US-Forest-Service-Uinta-Wasatch-Cache-National-Forest-147726224920736/
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat.  Early fall snow storms occur regularly in this area during this hunt.  Most years the snow will melt off within a day or two.  Be prepared for dry or muddy conditions.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 39.6~4000 Avintaquin, 17000 Currant Creek~3700 Avintaquin, 13500 Currant Creek~18–20~19.3~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns: Deer on this unit migrate down in elevation for the winter and typically from West to East, with most of the deer wintering on or near Tabby WMA.
Mule Deer rut: The mule deer rut usually runs from mid Nov.-mid Dec. so it does not affect this hunt.
Recommended areas to hunt: There are numerous areas to hunt on this unit.
The areas surrounding Strawberry Reservoir and Currant Creek Reservoir are excellent for deer hunting. They are easy to access with many roads and trails and camping areas. This of course leads to many people hunting these areas. There are very few areas on this unit without a road in the general area. There is far less hunting pressure on the Avintaquin unit, but that is because the overall deer density is much lower and the terrain is more rugged. This unit has very large aspen stands that hold a lot of deer in the early fall. Many of the best bucks taken each year come from these aspen stands. In the summer there are deer in the more open higher areas, but once they get pressured by hunters they will move into the lower, thicker aspen stands. These areas are difficult to hunt, because of the leaves on the trees and fewer open areas to glass with optics. There are also many lower areas with several different browse species, including; oak brush, service berry, mountain mahogany, bitter brush, snow berry, sage brush, etc. These areas also have deer in them during the hunt, but at a lower density.

Some areas to hunt include the following:
Currant Creek Reservoir Area - high elevation, large aspen stands, very accessible, high deer density for the unit.
Low Pass Creek- near Currant Creek Reservoir, rough road, great for ATV’s, great for glassing up high.
West Fork of the Duchesne- limited ATV access, but open to trucks.
Chicken Creek/Race Track- popular area, but holds a lot of deer and bucks
CO-OP Creek –Very Popular area, near Highway 40, great camping, large aspen stands
Trout Creek- many bucks taken here opening weekend
Wildcat WMA – good access, flat on top, a lot of pressure, many yearling bucks taken here.
North Fork of Deep Creek – borders private land, limited access by road, great horse area
Tabby Mountain – great for ATV’s, better after snow storms, mostly public land.
Coleman Basin/Red Creek Mtn- SITLA land, some areas without roads, rough roads
Reservation Ridge –fewer deer, but fewer people
Strawberry Peak- High elevation, large areas near by with no road access, Cow Hollow, Slab Canyon, low deer density
Timber Canyon/Long Ridge- low deer density, rough terrain, better after storms, rough roads.



Dollar Ridge Fire Update – July 2018

In early July 2018 the Dollar Ridge Fire burned approximately 50,000 acres on the Avintaquin and Currant Creek subunits of the Wasatch Mountains unit. The fire started in the Strawberry River Corridor and areas burned include portions of the Strawberry River wildlife management area and the Wildcat wildlife management area. Wildfire can have both negative and positive consequences for habitat and wildlife. In the right circumstances, wildfire can be a very effective tool for improving wildlife habitat. At lower elevation winter ranges fire may be detrimental if it removes important wintering feed sources or opens a niche for invasive weeds. In mid to high elevations fire often removes old, decadent growth and allows for new plants with high nutritional value. Grasses and forbs with high nutritional value are usually the first plant communities to come back after a fire. Regeneration in aspen stands is triggered by fire and mountain browse communities are quick to rebound.

This fire mostly occurred in higher summer and transition ranges for big game. Based on current burned locations, we anticipate the effects of the Dollar Ridge Fire to be mostly positive for deer, elk and moose. We have observed that GPS collared moose and elk in the burn temporarily moved to adjacent habitats while the fire was actively burning, then moved back almost immediately after the active fire subsided. If we receive our normal late-summer monsoon weather pattern it is very likely the burned areas will have a flush of new growth or “green-up” prior to the hunting season.

Wildfire can change wildlife distribution. Removal of cover may make an area less desirable for wary animals. Conversely, a good fall green-up might actually pull animals out of adjacent areas into the newly burned areas. Don’t overlook burned areas when hunting as they can be good places to locate game.

In 2017 the Brian Head fire burned 71,000 acres, nearly 25% of the Panguitch unit. At the end of the 2017 hunting season there were very few complaints from hunters and hunter success rates were normal to above normal. The Wasatch is a large unit and there are many locations with good hunting that were not affected by the Dollar Ridge Fire. We anticipate good opportunities for sportsmen this fall despite disturbance from the fire. In the long term we expect wildlife to reap many benefits from this fire.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Voluntary: The DWR conducts random surveys for all general season hunts. You may be contacted via phone to participate in this survey.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, Private and Tribal Lands.  The public lands are primarily US Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley National Forest and by the Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest and Wildlife Management Areas managed by the UDWR.  This unit also includes large tracks of Ute Tribal lands that are close to non-tribal members. The Tribal lands are mostly on the Avintaquin subunit, but there is one large area of Tribal land on the Currant Creek subunit on Blacktail Mountain.  There is a large amount of private property on the unit as well, including many CWMU’s.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Tabby Mtn., Wildcat Cyn., Currant Creek, Rabbit Gulch, Horse Ridge, Lake Canyon, Skitzy, Strawberry River and Timber Canyon WMAs
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US National Forest Service. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
Ashley National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Duchese, Provo and Price USGS or BLM 1:100,000 topo maps
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION Central Federal Lands Highway Division (CFLHD), in partnership with Wasatch County, Utah County, and the United States Forest Service (USFS) is planning to improve Strawberry Sheep Creek Road, a 31.9 mile route between US-6 and US-40. This road is really 
ROAD CLOSURE CONSIDERATIONS The key objective is to construct these roadway improvements while minimizing impacts to public users. To facilitate public safety, certain segments of the road will be closed during various construction activities. When the road is open, delays up to 30 minutes can be expected. The construction schedule is subject to change. During road closures, no motorized vehicles will be permitted on the route. Adjacent Off Highway Vehicle (OHV) trail routes will continue to be open during road closures. Where a potential conflict between an OHV and construction equipment is possible, the OHV access will be restricted for public safety. Emergency access will be permitted at all times.
ROAD CLOSURE PRELIMINARY SCHEDULE
a combination of three smaller routes, Sheep Creek – Rays Valley Road (FR 70051); Unicorn Ridge – Indian Creek Road (FR 70042); and West Side Strawberry Road (FR 70131). The construction work will be split into four segments: Segment 1 (FR 70051) begins at the MP 0.0 (intersection with US-6) and ends at MP 7.0 (FR 70042). The work on Segment 1 consists of pavement rehabilitation including patching, crack sealing, and chip sealing. Segment 2 and Segment 3 (FR 70042) begins at MP 7.0 and ends at FR 70131. The work on Segment 2 and 3 consists of roadway bench widening, paving, drainage improvements, and safety improvements. Segment 4 (FR 70131) begins at the intersection with FR 70042 and ends 3.75 miles north of the intersection. The work on Segment 4 consists of pavement rehabilitation, pulverizing, and paving with subexcavation as needed.
QUESTIONS? Wasatch County Public Works 1891 West 3000 South Heber City, Utah 84032 435-654-1661 www.wasatch.utah.gov
Utah County
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at:
Ashley National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The hunt unit does not include Ute Tribal lands as shown on the hunt boundary map on the Division's website. There are many access roads across Tribal Lands, for information on which roads are legal access roads contact Duchesne County. All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands, they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal Lands.

There are many CWMU’s on this unit, General Season Deer Permits are not valid on CWMU’s. All other private land requires written permission before hunting.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Carbon, Duchesne, Utah and Wasatch counties—Boundary begins SR-87 and US-40 in Duchesne; north on SR-87 to SR-35; west on SR-35 to SR-32 at Francis; west on SR-32 to US-40; southeast on US-40 to Strawberry Bay Marina Road; south on this road to USFS Road 042 (Indian Creek); south and west on this road to USFS Road 051; south on this road to US-6; southeast on US-6 to US-191; north on US-191 to US-40; east on US-40 to SR-87 in Duchesne. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Duchesne, Nephi, Price, Provo, Salt Lake City. Boundary questions? Call the Springville office, 801-491-5678 or the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.
